item.title: Yet another blog
item.description:
Why write another tech blog?! Link to heading

I’ve been asking myself for about a year now, during which time I’ve created and deleted this blog several times because I thought I had nothing to say. All things said, videos made, tutorials written, problems solved.

BUT…

I think everyone has a different experience installing software, building hardware, and troubleshooting. We receive information and learn in diferent ways.

item.title: What is Homelab and why should you care?
item.description:
What is homelab and why should you care? Link to heading

Homelab is a place where IT enthusiasts and professionals can learn and experiment without having to risk damaging the production environment. It can be anything from a single older computer running a few services to a virtualization cluster of servers simulating corporate infrastructure.

Homelab is a unique opportunity to acquire skills and practical experience in IT. And if you’re just starting out as an IT administrator, homelab can open the door to the world of technology in a way that’s affordable, flexible, and above all, safe.

item.title: Chosing hardware for homelab
item.description:
So you want to build a homelab, but where do you even start?

You should think about the purpose for which you are purchasing a homelab. Hardware requirements will depend on your needs.

Most people who start with a homelab, want for example space for storing various media, or a way to view them on home devices. Others because they want to test new things for work. Or they want to start working in IT and need a place to learn it all.
